repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: Bundled 'vim' color scheme is written in Vimscript which
  implicitly assumes that the file is ported from Vim.
  This is not the case, at it is currently the Neovim's way of providing
  backward compatibility for color schemes.

Solution: Rewrite it in Lua to indicate that this runtime file comes
  from Neovim.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -41,7 +41,7 @@ module.nvim_argv = {
   -- Make screentest work after changing to the new default color scheme
   -- Source 'vim' color scheme without side effects
   -- TODO: rewrite tests
-  '--cmd', 'lua f=io.open("runtime/colors/vim.vim", "r"); l=f:read("*a"); f:close(); vim.api.nvim_exec2(l, {})',
+  '--cmd', 'lua dofile("runtime/colors/vim.lua")',

comment_data.body: I don't think that's necessary; you only use `set_hl` once and `vim.cmd` a handful of times.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,290 @@
+-- Name:         vim
+-- Description:  Vim's default color scheme
+-- Author:       Bram Moolenaar <Bram@vim.org>
+-- Maintainer:   The Vim Project <https://github.com/vim/vim>
+-- Website:      https://github.com/vim/vim
+-- License:      Same as Vim
+-- Last Updated: 2023 Aug 10
+
+-- This is Vim's default color scheme. It doesn't define the Normal
+-- highlighting, it uses whatever the colors used to be.
+
+vim.cmd('hi clear')
+vim.g.colors_name = 'vim'
+
+local set_hl, cmd = vim.api.nvim_set_hl, vim.cmd

comment_data.body:
This is working around `nvim_set_hl` erroring if `bg` or `fg` are not defined for the normal group? 

What's the rationale for setting these (non-defined) attributes here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,290 @@
+-- Name:         vim
+-- Description:  Vim's default color scheme
+-- Author:       Bram Moolenaar <Bram@vim.org>
+-- Maintainer:   The Vim Project <https://github.com/vim/vim>
+-- Website:      https://github.com/vim/vim
+-- License:      Same as Vim
+-- Last Updated: 2023 Aug 10
+
+-- This is Vim's default color scheme. It doesn't define the Normal
+-- highlighting, it uses whatever the colors used to be.
+
+vim.cmd('hi clear')
+vim.g.colors_name = 'vim'
+
+local set_hl, cmd = vim.api.nvim_set_hl, vim.cmd
+local hi = function(name, val)
+  -- Force links
+  val.force = true
+
+  -- Make sure that `cterm` attribute is not populated from `gui`
+  val.cterm = val.cterm or {}
+
+  -- Define global highlight
+  set_hl(0, name, val)
+end
+
+--stylua: ignore start
+-- General
+hi('Normal', {})
+
+cmd('hi Cursor  guifg=bg guibg=fg')

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
vim.cmd.highlight('clear')
```
(just an alternative suggestion; should be nanoseconds faster since the command need not be parsed)

comment_data.body:
For `vim.cmd()` - sure. It's just makes more aligned with `hi()` calls.
But `set_hl` is called on every `hi()` call. So unless there is some dark magic JIT involved, I think using local `set_hl` should be faster (by avoiding lookups of `vim.api`).

comment_data.body:
`hi('Normal', {})` is mimicking `hi Normal gui=NONE cterm=NONE` from Vimscript version.

Usage of `cmd()` is to work around the fact that 'fg' and 'bg' can't be set as attribute value in `vim.api.nvim_set_hl()`, yes. Otherwise, there are errors.

> What's the rationale for setting these (non-defined) attributes here?

Not sure which attributes is this about?

> Not sure which attributes is this about?

`guifg=fg` instead of the equivalent (and arguably more explicit) `guifg=NONE` (or just omitting it, since `nvim_set_hl` clears omitted attributes anyway)

> > Not sure which attributes is this about?
> 
> `guifg=fg` instead of the equivalent (and arguably more explicit) `guifg=NONE` (or just omitting it, since `nvim_set_hl` clears omitted attributes anyway)

It is `guifg=bg` and this is the way it was done in Vim's color scheme. So just mimicking here because I don't completely know why it is defined the way it is.

comment_data.body:
> So just mimicking here because I don't completely know why it is defined the way it is.

"20 year old tricky ways", if I had to guess.

I'd _really_ prefer if we could drop the hackery for our files, as long as the outcome is still the same.

comment_data.body:
Me too. The point here is that I can not vouch that using `hi('Cursor', {})` and `vim.cmd.highlight('Cursor  guifg=bg guibg=fg')` result in the same outcome.

I can replace it, though, of course. If all tests still pass, will this be enough?

comment_data.body:
Benchmarked similar to [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26658#issuecomment-1863260486).

Results were 557 ms with using `local set_hl` and 560 ms with plain `vim.api.nvim_set_hl` call inside `hi` call. So yeah, number of calls doesn't seem significant enough to justify using `local set_hl`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,290 @@

+-- highlighting, it uses whatever the colors used to be.
+
+vim.cmd('hi clear')
+vim.g.colors_name = 'vim'
+
+local set_hl, cmd = vim.api.nvim_set_hl, vim.cmd

comment_data.body:
Judging by resolved #25474, having `vim.cmd.highlight('Cursor  guifg=bg guibg=fg')` (or in `Ignore`, for that matter) is different from `vim.cmd.highlight('Cursor  guifg=NONE guibg=NONE')` in case of cleared `Normal`. Mostly because that `"fg"` and `"bg"` colors will be updated after `Normal` is updated.

By the way, this is contrary to [what is written in the help](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/49efdf84139a0c0f7ba0217e5ab665bc4f222206/runtime/doc/syntax.txt#L5076-L5078): it seems that changing `Normal` should not result into `"fg"` and `"bg"` colors being changed.

So I don't see a way of getting rid of those `vim.cmd.highlight()` calls for groups which use `"fg"` or `"bg"` as colors, as `vim.api.nvim_set_hl()` errors in that case (which is a [documented behavior](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/49efdf84139a0c0f7ba0217e5ab665bc4f222206/runtime/doc/api.txt#L1457-L1460)).

comment_data.body:
@bfredl is this something we can fix? I think the goal is to have nvim_set_hl be a full alternative to :highlight. 

(Otherwise I am fine with declaring this a &bg=&bg level hackery that was never explicitly promised to work.)

comment_data.body:
> By the way, this is contrary to [what is written in the help](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/49efdf84139a0c0f7ba0217e5ab665bc4f222206/runtime/doc/syntax.txt#L5076-L5078): it seems that changing Normal should not result into "fg" and "bg" colors being changed.

This means that we don't have to support this use case ("live" values of `fg` and `bg`) and `guifg=NONE` replicates the _documented_ behavior of `fg=bg`. So we _can_ (and should) get rid of the `vim.cmd.highlight` calls (except `clear`).

comment_data.body:
Not supporting this case will mean that `Cursor`, `lCursor`, and `Ignore` will not be the same as they are in Vim. I'd argue that ensuring advertised compatibilty has higher priority than not using `vim.cmd.highlight()`.

The best course of action is to make `nvim_set_hl()` behave the same way as `:hi` in this case.

comment_regular_data.body:
Personal preference: I think a table followed by a loop is cleaner:
```lua
local theme = {
 'Conceal'  =  { fg = 'LightGrey', bg = 'DarkGrey', ctermfg = 'LightGrey', ctermbg = 'DarkGrey' },
},
for k, v in pairs(theme) do
  v.force = true
  v.cterm = v.cterm or {}
  vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, k, v)
end
```
(If you want to keep your definitions in blocks, you can make the loop into a `set_hl(theme)` function and call that on each block; wouldn't even need to set a local table then.)
Sorry for the nitpicks; this will just become (intentionally or not) the official model for Lua colorschemes, and I'd like to make it as nice as possible in the face of possible cargo-culting.

> Personal preference: I think a table followed by a loop is cleaner:
> 
> ```lua
> local theme = {
>  'Conceal'  =  { fg = 'LightGrey', bg = 'DarkGrey', ctermfg = 'LightGrey', ctermbg = 'DarkGrey' },
> },
> for k, v in pairs(theme) do
>   v.force = true
>   v.cterm = v.cterm or {}
>   vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, k, v)
> end
> ```
> 
> (If you want to keep your definitions in blocks, you can make the loop into a `set_hl(theme)` function and call that on each block; wouldn't even need to set a local table then.)

I personally don't really see the point in having extra step of creating a table only to later iterate through it.

Having it in the table does not seem to be faster either. I did benchmarking for two files:
- One uses separate calls, as suggested in the PR.
- The other creates two tables (one for common highlight groups and one for groups depending on background) and then uses two `for` loops to iterate through each one.

Besides that, they are as similar as possible (use same `hi` wrapper, etc.).

I ran `dofile('path/to/colorscheme.lua')` 10000 times for each file registering execution of `dofile()` in as much similar conditions as I reasonably could make. Here are the results:

- Usage of calls: 551 ms median time.
- Usage of table: 558 ms median time.

As 7 microseconds don't look significant here (~1.25%), I'd conclude that there is no sizable difference here. And using calls look cleaner as it omits extra unnecessary step.
As I said, personal preference. The individual hi calls are fine.

Pushed an update which only removes `local set_hl, cmd = ...` and instead uses those functions directly.

Groups which use `"fg"` or `"bg"` colors still need `vim.cmd.highlight()` approach as explained in [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26658#discussion_r1431803338).

> Groups which use `"fg"` or `"bg"` colors still need `vim.cmd.highlight()` approach as explained in [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26658#discussion_r1431803338).

Pushed an update that doesn't set `"fg"` and `"bg"` colors if they are used in Vim color scheme in favor of having `nvim_set_hl()` be the only way to define highlight group. This currently affects `Cursor`, `lCursor`, and `Ignore` highlight groups. The reasoning is in [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26658#discussion_r1432764574).
Merging now to unblock the followup PRs.

title: refactor(runtime): rewrite 'vim' color scheme in Lua
